==Czech== ===Proper noun=== {{cs-proper noun}} # {{surname|cs}} ---- ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|gmh|vriunt}}, from {{inh|de|goh|friunt}}, from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*frijōndz||lover, friend}}, from a derivative of {{inh|de|ine-pro|*prēy-}}, {{m|ine-pro|*prāy-||to like, love}}. Compare {{cog|lb|Frënd}}, {{cog|nl|vriend}}, {{cog|nds|Fründ}}, {{cog|fy|freon}}, {{cog|en|friend}}, {{cog|da|frænde}}, {{cog|sv|frände}}, {{cog|no|frende}}, {{cog|fo|frændi}}, {{cog|is|frændi}}, {{cog|got|𐍆𐍂𐌹𐌾𐍉𐌽𐌳𐍃}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/frɔʏ̯nt/|[fʁɔʏ̯nt]}} * {{audio|de|De-at-Freund.ogg|audio (Austria)}} ===Noun=== {{de-noun|m|Freundes|gen2=Freunds|Freunde|f=Freundin}} # [[friend]] #: {{ux|de|Lass uns '''Freunde''' bleiben.|Let’s stay '''friends'''.}} # [[boyfriend]] #: {{ux|de|Hast du einen '''Freund'''?|Do you have a '''boyfriend'''?}} # {{lb|de|obsolete}} [[blood relative]] (in the sense of a person that is or should be one’s friend by nature) ====Usage notes==== * ''Freund'' (and ''Freundin'') may refer to either a platonic friend or a romantic partner. When used in the singular with a possessive (''mein Freund, ihr Freund'', etc.), the word usually has a romantic implication, unless the context suggests otherwise. * Most derived terms, such as {{m|de|befreundet}} or {{m|de|Freundschaft}}, are restricted to the platonic sense, however. ====Declension==== {{de-decl-noun-m|(e)s|e}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|de|anfreunden}} * {{l|de|befreunden}}, {{l|de|befreundet}} * {{l|de|Blutsfreund}} * {{l|de|Brieffreund}} * {{l|de|Busenfreund}} * {{l|de|entfreunden}} * {{l|de|freundlich}} * {{l|de|Freundschaft}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}}
